document.masterDocTitle: Taxonomic assessment of genetically-delineated species of radicine snails (Mollusca, Gastropoda, Lymnaeidae)

subSubSection.paragraph: 10. Ampullaceana ampla (W. Hartmann, 1821) Figs 7A, B ; 8A ; Table 2
Limneus auricularia var. ampla Hartmann 1821 : 250, Taf. II, fig. 29.
Lymnaea (Peregriana) patula - Kruglov and Starobogatov 1993b : 166, fig. 6D ( Lymnaea ), non Da Costa 1778; Kruglov 2005 : 351, figs 236( 4-5) ; 241, 242.

Radix ampla -
Gloeer 2002
: 215, fig. 243;
Gloeer 2019
: 235, fig. 293.
Germany, Bavaria, Rhein River near Reineck.

subSubSection.paragraph:
A. ampla
is distributed in Europe (except the northernmost and southernmost latitudes), Western Siberia and the southern part of Eastern Siberia (
Gloeer 2002
, 2019 ;
Vinarski and Gloeer 2007
; Andreeva et al. 2011; Welter-Schultes 2012 ). The shell of this species is relatively large, with low spire and very expanded aperture; conchologically,
A. ampla
can sometimes be confused with
R. auricularia
; however, the former species has straight or virtually absent columellar fold, which is not characteristic for
R. auricularia
. Shell height may reach 30-32 mm. The lengths of the praeputium and the penis sheath in this species are roughly equal (see Fig. 8A ), with ICA close to 1.00. In a sample of
A. ampla
( n = 52), collected from several water-bodies of Russia, ICA was equal to 0.88 +/- 0.13 (min - max = 0.51-1.21).

Table 2. Morphological characterisation of shells and copulative apparatuses of several species in the genera
